thread.title: Japanese Bulk Carrier Files for Bankruptcy Protection
thread.title_full: Japanese Bulk Carrier Files for Bankruptcy Protection - WSJ

author: Megumi Fujikawa
title: Japanese Bulk Carrier Files for Bankruptcy Protection
text:
0 COMMENTS Japanese bulk-shipping carrier Daiichi Chuo Kisen Kaisha 9132 -3.45 % filed for bankruptcy protection in Tokyo on Tuesday, with debt totaling ¥176.5 billion ($1.5 billion) including its wholly-owned subsidiary Star Bulk Carrier Co.
The company said its earnings have deteriorated in recent years due to “unprecedented long-term depression in the maritime transportation market” triggered by Europe’s financial crisis as well as the slowdown in the Chinese economy.
Bulk shippers are getting hammered as demand for commodities has plummeted and ship charter rates have collapsed.
Daiichi Chuo Kisen Kaisha is the second bulk shipping business to file for bankruptcy protection this month. Global Maritime Investments Cyprus Ltd. filed for bankruptcy protection Sept. 15 and said it would wind down its business.
Following the bankruptcy announcement, the Tokyo Stock Exchange said the shipper’s shares will be delisted from the bourse’s first section on Oct. 30.
Trading of the company’s shares was halted Tuesday. But shares of Mitsui O.S.K . 9104 -7.40 % Lines, which holds a 21.8% stake in the company as of March 31, were hit hard by the news, and are currently down 8% to ¥286.
The company also filed for bankruptcy protection in the U.S. Tuesday in New York under chapter 15, the section of the bankruptcy code dealing with international insolvencies. Shipping companies restructuring overseas often file for chapter 15 to protect their vessels and other assets in the U.S. from being seized by creditors.
Write to Megumi Fujikawa at megumi.fujikawa@wsj.com
